text:
Your people are the key to your
success with the cloud.

That’s why it’s so important
to not only motivate and train

them, but to also give them
opportunities to put their

training into practice with
first-hand experience.

The first step in this process
is to get buy-in.

Buy-in is an understanding,
agreement, and commitment

from those who you need support
from in order to achieve
your goals.

Getting buy-in from the top aligns
your organization around a common
goal.

It positions the cloud as a company
priority rather than an IT priority.

It helps everyone in the organization
understand that embracing

the cloud will have a positive
impact, not only on IT, but in
every area of the business.

Getting buy-in from your peers
will increase the likelihood

that they will work with you,
and as stakeholders

will provide you with the support
you’ll need.

And getting buy-in from your
team helps them see your company’s

cloud adoption as something
positive: as the opportunity

that it truly is—an opportunity
to learn new skills that can
transform their careers.

This means that you probably
already have the people that

you need to be successful
with the cloud.

Your existing employees
are already familiar with your

company, processes, people,
and systems.

It’s often far easier to bridge
your organization’s

skills gap by providing
your existing employees

with cloud training than it is
to try to hire externally.

This tends to not only be more
cost-effective, but also fosters

a sense of comradery,
teamwork, and morale—many

of the things that will be critical
to your success.

Investing in training and certification
can produce an outsized
return on investment.

And when you combine your team’s
training with first-hand

experience, it makes the training
relevant, and motivates

employees to take full advantage
of it.

When you combine this with new
career paths for the cloud,

it creates incentives
for them to continue to learn,

and for them to be fully invested
in your organization’s
cloud journey.
